instruction:
You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.

I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output: It sounds like you have already tried a few approaches to engage your friend in conversation, but to no avail. It is understandable that you want to enjoy your trip and that your friend's behavior is detrimental to that. It might be helpful to have a conversation with him about how his behavior is making you feel. You could say something like, "I know that you don't seem to be enjoying the trip as much as I had hoped, and I wanted to let you know that it's making me feel really bad. I know that you have the right to feel however you want, but I wanted to let you know how I'm feeling so that you are aware." This approach might help him understand how his behavior is affecting you, and it might help him be more mindful of your feelings in the future.

output:
The OneLove campaign was created by the European Football Union in order to promote inclusion and oppose discrimination. It was inspired by the work of ten European football teams, including the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, and Wales, who had come together to show their support.

The teams were motivated by the increasing number of reports of discrimination and exclusionary behavior in football stadiums. They wanted to use their influence to create a positive change and show that football fans should be welcomed and respected regardless of their backgrounds.

The OneLove campaign was launched with the slogan “Football Fans United Against Discrimination”. It included a series of activities such as workshops, educational materials, and social media campaigns that aimed to raise awareness and encourage people to speak out against discrimination.

The campaign was a success, and it was praised for helping to create a more inclusive atmosphere in football stadiums. It also encouraged other sports teams and leagues to follow suit and create their own initiatives to promote inclusion and diversity.

instruction:
A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output:
We are looking for a talented and experienced Software Engineer to join our team. The successful candidate will be responsible for developing, testing, and debugging complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.

The ideal candidate will have experience with a modern software programming language, such as Python, and Pyspark. They should also have experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure, as well as strong written and verbal communication skills. Experience with visualization tools such as Tableau or PowerBI is also desirable.

The successful candidate will be able to work collaboratively with other engineers and stakeholders, and have the ability to diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects. They should have an eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment.

Section Title: Trusty Jeans
Main point of the section: jeans can be worn all year and look good with everything .

When it comes to packing for a trip, it can be difficult to know what pieces are worth taking up precious space in your suitcase. Luckily, one classic item that can be worn all year round and looks good with everything is a trusty pair of jeans. Denim is a classic wardrobe staple that can be dressed up or down, making it a great option for any vacation. Whether you’re looking to add a pop of color or keep it classic with a neutral hue, there are plenty of fall fashion trends in jeans that can help you look stylish and feel comfortable while on your trip. 

One of the biggest trends in jeans this fall is the use of bold colors and prints. From bright reds and oranges to funky, abstract prints, these jeans will add a pop of personality to any outfit. If you’re looking to make a statement, these jeans are a great way to do it. 

Another popular trend this season is the use of distressed and frayed denim. Whether you’re looking for a vintage or modern look, these jeans can add an edgy, yet timeless touch to any outfit. 

For those who want to keep it classic, there are plenty of neutral hues and washes to choose from. From dark indigo to light gray, these jeans will add a timeless and classic look to any outfit. 

No matter what look you’re going for, there are plenty of fall fashion trends in jeans that can help you look stylish and feel comfortable while on your trip. Whether you’re looking to make a statement or keep it classic, there’s something for everyone this season.

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Step 1: Identify the Conflict

The first step in resolving a GitHub merge conflict is to identify the conflict. Look through the conflict markers in the merge conflict UI and make sure you understand which lines of code are in conflict.

Step 2: Understand the Conflict

Once you have identified the conflict, take some time to understand the conflict. Look through the conflicting lines of code and try to understand why there is a conflict. This will help you better understand how to resolve the conflict.

Step 3: Resolve the Conflict

Now that you understand the conflict, it's time to resolve it. There are a few different approaches you can take, but the most common is to use a three-way merge tool. This tool will allow you to compare the conflicting lines of code and create a resolution that both sides can agree on.

Step 4: Test and Commit the Resolution

Once you have resolved the conflict, it's important to test and commit the resolution. Test the resolution to make sure it works as expected and then commit it to your repository. This will resolve the conflict and move you closer to merging the branches.

Step 5: Merge the Branches

Once you have committed the resolution, it's time to merge the branches. This will bring the changes from the conflicting branch into your repository.

Step 6: Push the Resolution

Once the merge is complete, it's important to push the resolution to your remote repository. This will make sure that the changes are available to all users on the repository.

Step 7: Celebrate!

Resolving a merge conflict can be a difficult task, so once you have successfully resolved it, it's important to celebrate your accomplishment. Take a break, treat yourself, or just take a moment to appreciate your hard work.

instruction:
Answer the following question.

How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?
output: The == operator in Java is used to compare two objects reference-wise. It checks if two references point to the same object. It is true that == should not be used to compare strings, as it compares the references, not the content. Instead, the .equals() method should be used to compare strings, as it compares the content. The difference between == and .equals() is that == compares references, while .equals() compares the content.

instruction:
Provide a Java solution to the following problem.

Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?
output:
Yes, it is possible to solve this problem without loops or recursion. Here is one solution:

We can use modulo arithmetic to check if n is a multiple of 3. 

First, calculate the remainder of n when divided by 3: 

n % 3

If the remainder is 0, then n is a multiple of 3. 

If n % 3 != 0, then n is not a multiple of 3. 

Thus, we can solve this problem without loops or recursion.

instruction:
You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.

Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output: This SQL query uses a left join to report the first and last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table, even if there is no address associated with that person. The result table will contain the first and last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table, with nulls where there is no address associated with that person.

instruction:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output: Art and mathematics have a long and intertwined history, with artists using mathematics to create works of art and mathematicians using art to illustrate mathematical concepts. Examples include the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, as well as the use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry in the work of M. C. Escher. Mathematics has also inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, and weaving, as well as Islamic art forms like girih and zellige tilework, and Mughal jali and muqarnas vaulting.

instruction:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.

The fair trade movement seeks to address the inequalities and exploitation in global trade. It advocates for better working and wage conditions, environmental sustainability, and the empowerment of marginalized communities in the South. It also seeks to increase access to markets for small-scale farmers and producers in the South, and to improve their access to resources and technology.

Fair trade certification is a type of social labeling that ensures that products have been produced in accordance with fair labor and environmental standards. It is based on the principles of fairness, transparency, and accountability. In order to receive fair trade certification, producers must meet certain criteria, such as paying fair wages, providing safe and healthy working conditions, and using environmentally sustainable practices.

The fair trade movement has been both praised and criticized. Its proponents argue that it has improved the lives of marginalized producers in the South, while its detractors argue that it has failed to live up to its ideals and has done little to improve the lives of those it seeks to help.

Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.

Il s'agit d'étudier, de diagnostiquer, de prévenir, de gérer et de traiter les maladies, les désordres et les conditions de la bouche, avec une attention particulière portée sur la dentition (la formation et l'arrangement des dents) ainsi que l'oral mucosa. La pratique de la dentistry peut inclure d'autres aspects du complexe craniofacial, comme le joint temporomandibulaire. Les professionnels de la dentistry sont appelés des dentistes.

instruction:
Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose.

Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)
output:
This course is designed to introduce students to the world of programming with Python. We will cover the basics of the Python language, including syntax, data types, and functions. We will also cover how to use Python to create simple programs and applications. By the end of the course, students should have a solid understanding of the fundamentals of Python programming and be able to create basic programs.

Chapter 1: Introduction to Python

In this chapter, we will introduce the Python programming language and its main features. We will discuss the history of Python, its syntax, data types, and functions. We will also cover how to use Python to create simple programs and applications.

Chapter 2: Working with Strings

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to manipulate and create strings. We will cover how to create, modify, and join strings, as well as how to use regular expressions to search and replace text. We will also cover how to use Python to generate reports and documents.

Chapter 3: Working with Numbers

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to work with numbers. We will cover how to create and manipulate integers, floats, and complex numbers. We will also cover how to use Python to solve mathematical problems and generate reports with numerical data.

Chapter 4: Working with Lists and Tuples

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to create and manipulate lists and tuples. We will cover how to create, modify, and extend lists and tuples, as well as how to use them to store and manipulate data. We will also cover how to use Python to create efficient data structures and how to use list comprehensions to process large amounts of data.

Chapter 5: Working with Classes and Objects

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to create classes and objects. We will cover how to create classes, how to use objects to store data, and how to use object-oriented programming to create complex applications. We will also cover how to use Python to create custom exceptions and how to use inheritance to extend existing classes.

Chapter 6: Using Modules and Libraries

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to use existing modules and libraries. We will cover how to install and use Python packages, how to use modules to extend the Python language, and how to use libraries to create complex applications. We will also cover how to use Python to create and use custom modules and libraries.

Chapter 7: Automating Tasks with Python

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python to automate tasks. We will cover how to use Python to create scripts and automate repetitive tasks. We will also cover how to use Python to create automation tools and how to use the Python Standard Library to automate system tasks.

Chapter 8: Using Python in the Real World

In this chapter, we will discuss how to use Python in the real world. We will cover how to use Python to create complex applications, how to use Python in the workplace, and how to use Python to create efficient and effective solutions. We will also cover how to use Python to create web applications and how to use Python to create software products.

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
Here are some tips to help students keep their nerves under control during class presentations:

1. Practice and prepare ahead of time. Knowing your material inside and out will help you feel more confident.

2. Take deep breaths and focus on your breathing. This can help calm your body and mind.

3. Rehearse your presentation out loud. This will help you become familiar with your material and build your confidence.

4. Use visual aids to help you present your material. This can help you feel more comfortable and in control.

5. Practice positive affirmations. Repeating positive statements can help you feel more confident.

6. Ask questions if you don't know the answer. It's okay not to know everything.

7. Focus on the audience. Make eye contact with the people in your audience and focus on engaging them.

8. Don't be afraid to take a few moments to collect your thoughts. If you need a moment to collect your thoughts, don't be afraid to take it.

9. Don't be too hard on yourself. Making mistakes is an opportunity to learn and grow.

10. Practice, practice, practice. The more you practice, the more comfortable you will become.

1. Gather the necessary materials: an empty beer can, modeling clay, plastic bottle, plastic cup, glue, and paint.

2. Carefully cut away the top and bottom of the beer can, leaving about a 1-inch border.

3. Use modeling clay to create the details of the steam engine, such as the cylinders, piston, and valves.

4. Glue the plastic bottle and cup onto the beer can, forming the boiler.

5. Paint the model according to your desired color scheme.

6. Let the paint dry completely before moving on to the next step.

7. Carefully glue the plastic parts, such as the whistle, onto the model.

8. Add any additional details, such as smoke stacks, that you desire.

9. Let the glue dry completely before testing your steam engine.

10. Fill the plastic cup with warm water and add a few drops of dish detergent to create steam.

11. Place a few small pieces of paper around the engine to test its performance.

12. Enjoy your new steam engine!

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.

instruction: Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb.
output: In German, verbs always end in either -en, -n, or -t. Knowing this can help you avoid making mistakes when conjugating verbs. For example, the verb "to be" is "sein" in German, so it ends in "-t". Other verbs that end in "-t" include "to be", "to have", and "to do". Verbs that end in "-n" include "to be", "to have", and "to go". Verbs that end in "-en" include "to be", "to go", and "to do".

instruction: Come up with healthy and easy dinner ideas for weeknights.
output:
Here are some healthy and easy dinner ideas for weeknights:

1. Baked Salmon and Vegetables: Preheat oven to 375°F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Spread 1-2 tablespoons of olive oil over the salmon fillet and top with your favorite spices and herbs. Place the vegetables of your choice (e.g. broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, bell peppers) around the salmon and bake for 20-25 minutes.

2. Stir Fry Vegetables and Protein: Heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add chopped vegetables (e.g. bell peppers, mushrooms, zucchini, carrots) and cook for 5-7 minutes. Add your favorite protein (e.g. shrimp, chicken, tofu) and cook for an additional 5-7 minutes.

3. Buddha Bowl: Preheat oven to 375°F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Spread 1 tablespoon of olive oil over sweet potatoes and season with spices and herbs. Bake for 20-25 minutes. In a bowl, combine cooked quinoa, vegetables (e.g. bell peppers, zucchini, carrots), and your favorite dressing.

4. Vegetable and Bean Burrito Bowl: Heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Add diced vegetables (e.g. bell peppers, zucchini, carrots) and cook for 5-7 minutes. Add cooked black beans and season with spices and herbs. Serve in a bowl with your favorite toppings (e.g. salsa, sour cream, guacamole).

5. Vegetable and Egg Scramble: Heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Add diced vegetables (e.g. bell peppers, zucchini, carrots) and scramble with 2-3 eggs. Season with spices and herbs. Serve with your favorite toppings (e.g. salsa, sour cream).

instruction:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
Ingredients:
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cloves
- 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
- 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper
- 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt
- 1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened
- 1/2 cup vegetable oil
- 3 large eggs
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 2 cups granulated sugar
- 2 cups packed brown sugar
- 1 cup (75%) semi-sweet chocolate chips

Instructions:

1. Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Grease a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan with butter or cooking spray.

2. In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, ginger, cumin, and black pepper. Set aside.

3. In a large bowl, use an electric mixer to beat together butter, oil, eggs, vanilla, and sugars until light and fluffy. Beat in the dry ingredients until just combined. Stir in the chocolate chips.

4. Pour the cookie dough into the prepared pan and spread evenly. Bake for 20-25 minutes, until golden brown and a toothpick inserted into the center of the cookie comes out clean. Let cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Enjoy!

This medium-level sudoku puzzle contains 6x6 grids with bold outlines and a 3x3 box in the center. There are 30 cells with numbers 1-9 in a 6x6 grid. The objective is to fill in the empty cells with the correct numbers 1-9 such that each row, column, and 3x3 box contains all the numbers 1-9 without any repetitions. 

The puzzle starts with some numbers already filled in to give players an idea of where to start and which numbers are already present in the row, column, and 3x3 box. The difficulty level increases gradually as more numbers need to be filled in. There are hints available for players who get stuck.

The puzzle is solved when all 30 cells have the correct numbers 1-9 without any repetitions.

The solution to the Sudoku puzzle is:

1. 3
2. 8
3. 5
4. 6
5. 7
6. 1
7. 9
8. 4
9. 2

instruction:
Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.

A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output: The study published by Zee and her team examined the effects of light during sleep on healthy adults in their 20s. The results showed that exposure to dim light during sleep elevated the participants' blood sugar and heart rate, which are risk factors for future heart disease and diabetes.

instruction:
Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.

Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.
Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models
output: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder, with the encoder transforming an input into a representation and the decoder generating an output sequence based on the representation. These models have been successful in achieving state-of-the-art results in various tasks such as machine translation, but they require a lot of training time and computational resources. In their paper, the authors propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, which dispenses with recurrence and convolutions entirely and relies solely on attention mechanisms. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show that the Transformer achieves state-of-the-art results while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less training time. The authors also show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks such as English constituency parsing.

instruction:
Answer the question about the paper after reading it carefully.

To evaluate if the Transformer can generalize to other tasks we performed experiments on English constituency parsing. This task presents specific challenges: the output is subject to strong structural constraints and is significantly longer than the input. Furthermore, RNN sequence-to-sequence models have not been able to attain state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.
Question: What is English constituency parsing?
output: English constituency parsing is a task of analyzing sentences written in English and understanding their syntactic structure. It involves identifying and classifying the different components of a sentence, such as nouns, verbs, and adjectives, into predefined categories according to their syntactic roles. This task presents specific challenges, such as long output and strong structural constraints, which have made it difficult for RNN-based sequence-to-sequence models to achieve state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.

instruction:
Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.

We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method used in the research is end-to-end deep learning, which uses multiple GPUs and novel data synthesis techniques to train a RNN model that performs speech recognition. This approach does not rely on hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, and it outperforms previously published results on the Switchboard Hub5'00 test set with 16.0% error. It also performs better than commercial speech systems in noisy environments.

instruction:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.

Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: This paper introduces FewJoint, a new few-shot learning benchmark for dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. It provides a code platform and 59 dialogue domains from real industrial API to facilitate research in this field. To tackle the noisy sharing between two sub-tasks in the few-shot setting, the paper proposes a novel trust gating mechanism and a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy. The experiments show that the proposed method achieves new state-of-the-art performance on two datasets.

instruction:
Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA
output: The history of the United States is vast and complex, but there are some key points that are important to understand. The first colonists arrived in the 1600s, and the Thirteen Colonies declared independence from Britain in 1776. The American Revolution lasted until 1783, when the United States officially became an independent nation. The US Constitution was ratified in 1788, and the first president, George Washington, was elected in 1789. The Civil War began in 1861 and ended in 1865, and the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments were ratified during Reconstruction. The Industrial Revolution transformed the US in the late 1800s, and women's suffrage was achieved in 1920. The Great Depression and World War II shaped the 1930s and 1940s, and the civil rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s led to major changes in US society.

instruction:
Using the ingredients that are available, create a dinner recipe.

Kale + almond butter + apple cider vinegar + agave nectar + tamari
output:
Kale and Almond Butter Pesto:

Ingredients:
- 2 large handfuls of kale, stems removed and chopped
- 2 tablespoons almond butter
- 1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar
- 1 tablespoon agave nectar
- 2 tablespoons tamari

Instructions:

1. Preheat oven to 350°F.

2. In a food processor, combine kale, almond butter, apple cider vinegar, agave nectar, and tamari. Blend until smooth.

3. Spread the pesto onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Bake for 10 minutes, stirring halfway through.

4. Remove the baking sheet from the oven and let cool. Transfer the pesto to a jar and store in the fridge for up to 1 week.

5. Serve the pesto on top of your favorite pasta, spread on toast, or as a dip for vegetables. Enjoy!

instruction: How can I improve my time management skills?
output: Improving time management skills involves understanding how much time is needed for different tasks, breaking down tasks into smaller chunks, setting deadlines, and being organized. It also involves being aware of distractions and procrastination, and learning how to prioritize tasks. Taking a time management class or reading a book on the subject can also help improve your skills.

instruction: What are the most effective ways to deal with stress?
output: The most effective ways to deal with stress include identifying and avoiding triggers, developing healthy coping mechanisms, exercising regularly, getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and engaging in relaxing activities such as yoga, meditation, and deep breathing.

instruction: What are the main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages?
output: The main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages are in their syntax, data types, and scope. Python is a general purpose programming language that is both object-oriented and structured, while JavaScript is mainly used for web development. Python is a more expressive language, while JavaScript is more concise. Python is a compiled language, while JavaScript is a scripting language. Python is strongly typed, while JavaScript is weakly typed. Python has a more structured approach to code organization, while JavaScript is more loosely structured. Python is more popular for backend development, while JavaScript is more popular for frontend development.

instruction: How can I increase my productivity while working from home?
output: There are many ways to increase productivity while working from home. Setting goals and creating a schedule can help you stay on track and focused. It can also help to create a workspace that is free from distractions and clutter. Taking breaks throughout the day and engaging in physical activity can also boost productivity. Additionally, it can be helpful to limit your internet usage and set boundaries between your work and personal life.

instruction: Can you explain the basics of quantum computing?
output: Quantum computing is a technology that makes use of quantum mechanical phenomena to perform operations on data. Unlike traditional computing, which relies on bits that represent either 0 or 1, quantum computing uses quantum bits, or qubits, which can represent multiple values at once. This allows quantum computers to solve certain problems much faster than traditional computers. Quantum computing also has the potential to solve problems that are intractable on classical computers.

instruction: What are the differences between plant-based and animal-based protein sources?
output: The main difference between plant-based and animal-based protein sources is that plant-based proteins are derived from plants, while animal-based proteins are derived from animals. Plant-based proteins include legumes, nuts, seeds, and grains, while animal-based proteins include meat, eggs, and dairy products. Plant-based proteins are typically lower in calories and fat than animal-based proteins, and they are often richer in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. Plant-based proteins are also typically easier to digest than animal-based proteins.

instruction: How can I develop my critical thinking skills?
output: Developing critical thinking skills involves actively and regularly engaging in activities that challenge your assumptions and force you to think analytically. Examples of these activities include reading books and articles, participating in debates, solving puzzles and brainteasers, and playing strategy games. Taking courses in logic, philosophy, and argumentation can also help you hone your critical thinking skills.

instruction: What are the major challenges faced by the education sector today?
output: The major challenges faced by the education sector today include inadequate funding, overcrowded classrooms, lack of access to technology, and teacher shortages. Additionally, there are issues related to the quality of education, such as lack of access to meaningful instruction, inadequate support for students, and inadequate resources for professional development for teachers.

instruction: What are the primary factors that influence consumer behavior?
output: The primary factors that influence consumer behavior include social and cultural influences, personal values and beliefs, past experiences, and perceived consequences. Social and cultural influences include peer pressure, family influences, and the culture at large. Personal values and beliefs influence how a consumer perceives and interprets information. Past experiences influence how a consumer reacts to certain products or marketing campaigns. Finally, perceived consequences influence how a consumer weighs the costs and benefits of a purchase.

instruction: What are the most effective strategies for conflict resolution in the workplace?
output: The most effective strategies for conflict resolution in the workplace include active listening, constructive dialogue, cooperation, and compromise. It is important to understand the underlying causes of the conflict and to be open to finding solutions that satisfy both parties. Additionally, it is important to maintain respect and remain professional during the resolution process.

instruction: What are some potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health?
output:
The use of single-use plastic bottles has a number of potential implications for both the environment and human health. From an environmental perspective, single-use plastic bottles are not biodegradable and can take hundreds of years to decompose. This can lead to the accumulation of plastic waste in landfills and oceans, which can harm wildlife and ecosystems. Additionally, the production of single-use plastic bottles requires the use of fossil fuels, which can contribute to air and water pollution.

From a human health perspective, single-use plastic bottles can leach chemicals into the contents they contain, which can be harmful if consumed. Reusable bottles, on the other hand, do not have this potential health risk. Furthermore, single-use plastic bottles are not designed to be reused, which can lead to the spread of bacteria and other contaminants. This can potentially lead to illnesses if the contents of the bottle are consumed.

instruction: What factors would you consider when designing an inclusive and accessible public transportation system?
output:
When designing an inclusive and accessible public transportation system, factors to consider include:

1. Accessibility for people with disabilities, including those who use wheelchairs, canes, crutches, or other assistive devices.

2. Accessibility for people with visual or hearing impairments, including providing sign language interpreters or audio announcements.

3. Accessibility for people with limited English proficiency, including providing multilingual signage and announcements.

4. Accessibility for people with cognitive disabilities, including providing clear and consistent signage and information.

5. Accessibility for people with diverse racial, ethnic, and religious backgrounds, including providing culturally sensitive materials and services.

6. Accessibility for people with limited income, including providing discounted fares or fare subsidies.

7. Accessibility for people with diverse gender identities and expressions, including providing gender-neutral bathrooms and other gender-inclusive services.

8. Accessibility for people with diverse abilities, including providing accessible vehicles and stops, as well as training for staff and drivers.

9. Accessibility for people with limited mobility, including providing accessible vehicles, stops, and assistance from staff and drivers.

10. Accessibility for people with pets, including allowing service animals and providing pet-friendly vehicles and stops.

instruction: How can governments utilize fiscal and monetary policies to combat economic recessions?
output: Governments can utilize fiscal and monetary policies to combat economic recessions by increasing spending, cutting taxes, and increasing the money supply to stimulate economic growth. Fiscal policy involves government spending and taxation, while monetary policy involves increasing the money supply to encourage lending and investment. These policies can help to boost economic activity and reduce unemployment.

instruction: How do language and cultural barriers affect the way people communicate and form relationships in multicultural societies?
output: Language and cultural barriers can create challenges when it comes to forming relationships and communicating in multicultural societies. These barriers can lead to misunderstandings, mistrust, and a lack of understanding between different cultural and linguistic groups. This can lead to feelings of isolation, loneliness, and depression, as people may feel like they are unable to connect with those around them. It can also lead to a lack of understanding and respect for different cultures and perspectives. In order to bridge these gaps, it is important to recognize and acknowledge the different cultural and linguistic backgrounds of those around us, and to make an effort to understand and appreciate them.

instruction: Describe a scenario where artificial intelligence could be used to improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare delivery.
output: AI can be used to improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare delivery in a variety of ways. For example, AI can be used to automate administrative tasks such as scheduling, billing, and patient intake. AI can also be used to automate certain diagnostic processes, such as analyzing images or interpreting test results. AI can also be used to improve the accuracy and efficiency of diagnosis and treatment by providing decision support to healthcare providers. AI can also be used to automate certain aspects of patient care, such as managing medications or providing remote monitoring and support.

instruction: Explain the process of gene editing using CRISPR-Cas9 technology, and discuss its potential applications and ethical implications.
output: CRISPR-Cas9 is a powerful gene editing technology that uses RNA to guide an enzyme to a specific location in the genome, where it makes a precise change to the DNA sequence. It has the potential to correct genetic diseases, improve crops and livestock, and even create novel biological products. However, it also carries ethical concerns, such as the potential for designer babies and unintended consequences. It is important to carefully consider the implications of this technology before it is used.

instruction: How do vaccinations work to protect individuals and communities from infectious diseases, and what is herd immunity?
output: Vaccinations work by introducing a weakened or inactive form of a virus or bacteria into the body. This stimulates the body's immune system to produce antibodies that protect against illness. Herd immunity is a concept in public health that describes how vaccinations can protect not only the individual who is vaccinated, but also those around them. When a large percentage of the population is immune to a certain disease, either through vaccination or having already contracted the disease, it becomes more difficult for the disease to spread from person to person. This reduces the overall incidence of the disease in the population.

instruction: How do social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news, and what are the potential implications for the spread of misinformation?
output: Social media platforms have become an important source of news for many people, which can influence how people consume and share news. This can have both positive and negative implications. On the one hand, social media can help spread news faster and reach a wider audience. On the other hand, it can be easier for misinformation to spread on social media, which can lead to the spread of false or misleading information. This can lead to confusion and mistrust among users, which can be damaging to both individuals and society as a whole.

instruction: How do cultural, social, and economic factors influence people's food choices, and how can this knowledge be used to promote healthier diets?
output:
Cultural, social, and economic factors can all influence people's food choices. For example, cultural factors such as family customs and traditions can influence what types of food people grow accustomed to eating. Social factors such as peer pressure and the desire to fit in can influence people's food choices. Economic factors such as income level, access to certain foods, and cost can also influence people's food choices. 

Using this knowledge, health promotion strategies can be designed to target these factors. For example, providing education and resources to help people make healthier choices, or providing incentives for people to make healthier choices, can help to promote healthier diets.

instruction: Explain the process of natural selection and how it contributes to the evolution and adaptation of species.
output: Natural selection is the process by which certain traits or characteristics become more or less common over time based on which organisms are more successful in surviving and reproducing. These successful traits or characteristics become more common in subsequent generations, while less successful traits become less common. Over time, this process can lead to the evolution and adaptation of species as they become better suited to their environment.

instruction: If you were a Shakespearean character, how would you declare your love for someone in a soliloquy?
output:
Oh, sweetheart, let me count the ways I love you.
I love your beauty, so perfect and true.
I love the way you make me feel,
When I'm alone with you, so real.

I love the way you listen and accept,
The words I whisper, so tenderly craft.
I love the way you look at me,
With eyes that sparkle, so serenely.

I love the way you make me laugh,
And the way you make me sigh.
I love the way you care for me,
And the way you make me fly.

I love the way you make me feel,
When I'm in your arms, so complete.
I love the way you love me,
And the way you make me believe.

I used these powers to help people in need, and to fight against evil forces that wanted to harm the world. I was determined to use my gifts to make the world a better place, and so I became a superhero.

instruction: Imagine you are a time traveler from the year 3000. What technological advancements would you tell people about?
output: As a time traveler from the year 3000, I would tell people about the amazing advancements in technology that have occurred in the future. instruction: Implement a Python function to find the longest common subsequence of two input strings using dynamic programming.
output:
def lcs(s1, s2): 
    n1 = len(s1) 
    n2 = len(s2) 
  
    # Initialize the LCS array 
    lcs = [[0]*n2 for _ in range(n1)] for _ in range(n2)] 
  
    # Calculate LCS for all prefixes of s1 
    for i in range(n1): 
        for j in range(0, n2-i-1): 
            lcs[j][i] = min(lcs[j+1][i], lcs[j][i+1]) 
  
    # Return the LCS 
    return lcs[n1-1][n2-1]

instruction: Implement a regular expression in Python to validate an email address.
output:
The Python Standard Library provides a regular expression for validating email addresses, which is implemented as a function in the `re` module. It uses a combination of several other regular expressions to check for validity, including the presence of @, ., and - symbols, as well as a valid domain name. It also allows for a custom error message to be displayed if the email address is invalid.

The regular expression can be used as follows:

```python
import re

email_regex = re.compile(re.escape("^(?!.*@)[a-zA-Z0-9_.+-]+@$"), re.IGNORECASE)

def validate_email(email):
    result = email_regex.match(email)
    if result:
        return True
    else:
        return False

if __name__ == '__main__':
    email = 'example@example.com'
    print(f'Email address {email} is valid.')
    email = 'invalid@example.com'
    print(f'Email address {email} is invalid.')
```
